pull.title: build: libevent 2.1.12-stable
pull.body:
Start using [libevent 2.1.12-stable](https://github.com/libevent/libevent/releases/tag/release-2.1.12-stable) in depends. Changelog is available here: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/libevent/libevent/release-2.1.12-stable/ChangeLog. This release basically only contains bug fixes.

Upgrading will also prevent some oss-fuzz reports which are coming from libevent code, such as https://bugs.chromium.org/p/oss-fuzz/issues/detail?id=34355 & https://bugs.chromium.org/p/oss-fuzz/issues/detail?id=34412.

events.body:
<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

<!--174a7506f384e20aa4161008e828411d-->
### Conflicts
Reviewers, this pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* #21851 ([WIP] build: support cross-compiling for arm64-apple-darwin20 (Apple M1) in depends by fanquake)

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first.

> Changelog is available here: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/libevent/libevent/release-2.1.12-stable/ChangeLog.

Cannot find the reason why the patch could be dropped?
And the related https://github.com/libevent/libevent/issues/1041 is still open, btw.

issue.title: release: support cross-compiling for arm64-apple-darwin
issue.body:
With a few minor changes, our macOS toolchain, and Guix, supports building for `arm64-apple-darwin` (Apple M1). Newer [`config.guess`](https://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/config.git/plain/config.guess) and [`config.sub`](https://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/config.git/plain/config.sub) are required (via autoconf 2.71), as support for recognising `arm64-apple-darwin` [was only recently added](https://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/config.git/commit/?id=2593751ef276497e312d7c4ce7fd049614c7bf80). A newer version of the macOS SDK (11.0+) is also required; I've taken this from Xcode 12.2.

Guix Build:
```bash
bash-5.1# find guix-build-$(git rev-parse --short=12 HEAD)/output/ -type f -print0 | env LC_ALL=C sort -z | xargs -r0 sha256sum

events.body:
> Cannot find the reason why the patch could be dropped?

This is the relevant changelog entry:
>  o autoconf: fix getaddrinfo checking errors on mingw (b9bf7fa7 yuangongji)

which is [this commit](https://github.com/libevent/libevent/commit/6d54be2cc078351b4ce1e469bedc4a976f4e3636). The patch is small, so it's easy to verify that the changes are part of the newer libevent source.
~~cr ACK f152c1ac66bfe5c77d947d5c99ce5da3a88797fa: patch looks correct and this should resolve the OSS-Fuzz issues~~ ACK temporarily redacted while awaiting non-determinism fix

~ACK f152c1ac66bfe5c77d947d5c99ce5da3a88797fa~ [retracted due to non-reproducible builds](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/21991#issuecomment-844005749)

On master (6d1d33d33491a98bb0dbf64ea7e4743200e71474):
```
$ make -C depends libevent_configured HOST=x86_64-w64-mingw32 2>&1 | grep getaddrinfo
checking for getaddrinfo... yes
```

With this PR (f152c1ac66bfe5c77d947d5c99ce5da3a88797fa):
```
$ make -C depends libevent_configured HOST=x86_64-w64-mingw32 2>&1 | grep getaddrinfo
checking whether getaddrinfo is declared... (cached) yes
```

#### Guix builds:
```
$ find guix-build-$(git rev-parse --short=12 HEAD)/output/ -type f -print0 | env LC_ALL=C sort -z | xargs -r0 sha256sum

Hashes differ from ones in the OP.

(retracting my ACK for now)
Concept ACK, libevent changes in the changelog look fine to me. Lots of small fixes of which I'm not sure if they affect our use or not, but can't hurt either.
Probably, d2ccb92f8bfaa785bab094a02e2d858d55279930 could fix the guix builds determinism.

We've received another oss-fuzz report for libevent: https://bugs.chromium.org/p/oss-fuzz/issues/detail?id=34509. Note that all 3 linked here are the same underlying issue.

Given the determinism issue raised is not related to this PR, I'm still happy for this to merged as is.

comments.body: Oh, I see the `configure` has already been generated in the release archive.
